metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)-Dataset of flux observation matrix (eddy covariance system of Zhangye gobi desert station)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Bajitan Gobi station eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 31 May to 15 September, 2012. The site (100.30420° E, 38.91496° N) was located in Gobi surface, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1562.00 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.6 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500) was 0.15 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface?
Example.Answer: During HiWATER, several intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out using instruments arranged in hierarchically nested scales, such as a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interaction and superstations within the oasis, along with EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in different landscapes.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced is the effectiveness limitation of current composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions, where errors in derived component temperature are primarily caused by image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, leading to overestimation of canopy temperature under developing vegetation abundance.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes multi-scale and multidisciplinary data obtained from a specific eco-hydrological experiment?
Example.Answer: An example is the multiscale dataset from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER), which includes data obtained from a flux observation matrix, an eco-hydrological sensor network, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, and synchronical ground measurements, capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using eddy covariance systems compare to those using thermal infrared cameras in terms of accuracy and applicability for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection methods using eddy covariance systems focus on measuring turbulent fluxes of heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide directly, providing high-frequency data that require post-processing for quality control. These systems are often challenged by energy balance closure issues. In contrast, thermal infrared cameras are used to obtain soil and canopy component temperatures, which are then used in models like the TSEB to estimate evapotranspiration. This approach allows for separation of soil and vegetation fluxes, providing insights into the partitioning of evaporation and transpiration but is prone to errors in temperature estimation due to classification errors and environmental influences.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in accurately estimating surface fluxes in heterogeneous landscapes using models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors include the heterogeneity of landscapes that contain mixtures of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistance, challenges in measuring ground-based E and T, errors in composite temperature separation approaches, and uncertainties in derived component temperatures caused by image classification errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a challenge in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge arises due to the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is necessary for understanding and upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes of errors in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors are primarily caused by image classification errors which vary with vegetation abundance, leading to overestimations of canopy temperature. Other causes include ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation, transmittance uncertainties, and errors in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts of using multiscale observation experiments on the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Multiscale observation experiments can significantly enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation by capturing a diverse range of eco-hydrological processes across different scales. The use of instruments arranged in hierarchically nested scales, such as flux observation matrices and eco-hydrological sensor networks, allows for a comprehensive understanding of oasis-desert interactions and the separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures. This leads to more reliable estimates of latent and sensible heat fluxes, as demonstrated in the application of the TSEB model and other methodologies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of integrating ground-based measurements with high-precision thermal infrared cameras on the validation of evapotranspiration models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements with high-precision thermal infrared cameras can significantly improve the validation of evapotranspiration models by providing accurate soil and canopy component temperatures. This integration allows for a more precise estimation of E/ET% and T/ET% ratios, as well as reliable calculations of latent and sensible heat fluxes. The enhanced accuracy in temperature measurement facilitates the separation of soil and vegetation contributions to total evapotranspiration, thereby improving model performance even in strongly advective environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of utilizing multi-scale observation experiments in eco-hydrological studies over heterogeneous surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, as demonstrated in the HiWATER experiment.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement a two-source energy balance model when estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because the two-source energy balance model allows for more accurate estimation of surface evapotranspiration by considering the separate energy exchanges occurring at the soil and canopy levels, which is crucial in heterogeneous landscapes where soil and vegetation have different temperatures and resistances.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of integrating high-resolution thermal imagery with ground measurements in estimating soil and canopy temperatures?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes are to accurately estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by using soil and canopy component temperatures as inputs to the TSEB model, and to validate these estimates with observed ratios using stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in processing eddy covariance data to ensure quality and accuracy in measuring fluxes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of eddy covariance data involves several steps to ensure data quality and accuracy, including outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. The quality of each flux value is evaluated by testing atmospheric stationarity (Δst) and turbulence similarity characteristics (ITC). Additionally, data are filtered by removing readings when instruments malfunction, excluding data one hour before and after rainfall, and eliminating data with more than 3% missing rate in the 10 Hz original data every 30 minutes. Observations during low nighttime turbulence (u* less than 0.1 m/s) are also removed. Data are averaged over 30-minute periods, with missing data marked as -6999, and suspicious data due to instrument drift are highlighted in red.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are soil and canopy component temperatures derived and utilized in estimating evapotranspiration using the two-source energy balance model?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are derived using thermal images captured by a high-resolution thermal infrared camera. The visible and NIR images are classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. The brightness temperatures are extracted from these images and converted to radiation temperatures by accounting for incoming long-wave radiation and emissivity of the soil and canopy. These temperatures are used as inputs in the series two-source energy balance (TSEB) model to estimate soil and canopy sensible and latent heat fluxes by solving energy balance equations. The model's performance is validated against surface radiometric temperatures observed by a four-component radiometer.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of multi-scale eco-hydrological data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of an eddy covariance system with a flux observation matrix, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer has enabled the collection of multi-scale eco-hydrological data in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: What are the conditions that enable the successful application of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: The successful application of the TSEB model is enabled by using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, which are better validated with observed ratios of evaporation and transpiration using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, combined with eddy covariance measurements. Accurate calculation of soil and vegetation component temperatures is crucial for reliable estimates.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are anticipated in obtaining multiscale observational data for eco-hydrological processes in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: The poor availability of multiscale observations is a major challenge in eco-hydrological research, particularly in arid regions. The complexity of capturing processes across varying spatial scales and the need for hierarchically nested instrumentation to obtain comprehensive data make it difficult to progress in this field.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing datasets face difficulties in accurately partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration components?
Expectation.Answer: Existing datasets may face difficulties in partitioning evapotranspiration due to the limitations of current composite temperature separation approaches, particularly in arid regions. Errors in image classification and uncertainties in component temperatures can lead to inaccurate estimates of soil and canopy temperatures, impacting the partitioning of evaporation and transpiration.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the sufficiency of data collected during the 2012 intensive observation periods (IOPs) for understanding the oasis-desert interaction?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collected during the 2012 IOPs appear to be extensive and well-structured, involving instruments arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. This includes a sparse network for oasis-desert interaction investigation, a superstation within the oasis, and various EC towers and AMSs in different surrounding landscapes. While the dataset seems comprehensive, the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations remains a concern for thorough understanding.

Judgmental.Question: How do you perceive the potential of combining stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques with EC measurements for validating evapotranspiration estimates in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: Combining stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques with EC measurements is a promising approach for validating evapotranspiration estimates in heterogeneous landscapes. This method allows for better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by providing observed ratios, which can enhance the accuracy of models like TSEB. This approach seems to provide a robust solution for separating and validating soil and canopy fluxes, even under strongly advective conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively capture the complexities of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.
Assertion.Answer: The field employs a multiscale observation system which includes instruments arranged on hierarchically nested scales to capture these processes. This system consists of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and a variety of remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and microwave radiometers to address the challenge of capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the difficulties faced in ensuring data quality and accuracy in the collection of eco-hydrological data.
Assertion.Answer: In the field, the main challenges include the effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions and image classification errors that affect component temperature derivation. These issues lead to uncertainties in estimated temperatures and the subsequent calculations of energy fluxes. Furthermore, data quality is maintained through careful sensor calibration, data collection, and processing protocols.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets from remote sensing technologies contribute to understanding evapotranspiration in irrigated agricultural areas.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets from remote sensing technologies, such as those obtained from thermal infrared cameras and radiometric temperature measurements, are used to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures. These temperatures are critical for accurately partitioning evapotranspiration into its evaporation and transpiration components. The use of high-resolution remote sensing data allows for more precise estimates of these fluxes, even in strongly advective conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the primary data collection techniques utilized for observing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: The primary data collection techniques include the use of eddy covariance (EC) systems for turbulent flux measurements, meteorological parameters measured at specific heights, soil heat flux measurements using heat plates, and thermal infrared imaging for temperature data. Additionally, hierarchical and multi-scale instrumentation setups, such as flux observation matrices, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing (LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer), are employed to capture eco-hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the main challenges encountered in collecting multi-scale eco-hydrological data over heterogeneous surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenges include the poor availability of multi-scale observations and the limitations in composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions. Additionally, errors in image classification, atmospheric radiation influence, and uncertainties in radiation transmittance through the canopy present difficulties in accurately estimating surface fluxes, especially in strongly advective environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe potential datasets that could be utilized for validating eco-hydrological models in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include multiscale data from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER), which consist of flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data. These datasets include ground measurements of vegetation dynamics, photosynthesis processes, and synchronized meteorological data, which are useful for validating models such as the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in arid regions.
